AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: Grey in color, younger bark on branches and small trucks is corky. Older bark has vertical, rough, interlacing ridges and deep furrows. It is somewhat rough and spongy touch.

Rock elms are the least common elm tree of Minnesota’s elm trees. They are mostly found in the upper Mississippi Valley and the lower Great Lakes regions. Due the Dutch Elm Disease, the rock elm population has decreased significantly and unfortunately, unlike the American elm, very little effort has been made to create new disease resistant rock elm trees. Rock elm trees are often found in rich forested areas with other hard wood trees, in flood plains and along river and stream banks. Our specimen rock elm in the WSU Landscape Arboretum is found in between Minne Hall and Krueger Library. It was grown from seed found by one of our Arboretum Board members and nurtured in our tree nursery. With Dutch Elm Disease still in the area, specific maintenance practices will be employed to keep the elm healthy. We hope this is the first of many rock elms to be planted on our campus.
Small unshowy flower blooms in the early spring.
Winged samara, flat, egg shaped, 1/2- 7/8 inches long, dense soft hairs around the edge. Seeds disperse from May to June.
Simple, alternate, oval to ovate in shape coming to an acute point, 2-5 inches long, 1-3 inches wide, double-toothed edges, unequal leaf base.
Least common of the native elms, almost completely disappeared due to Dutch Elm Disease.
